column1: Will the team winning the 2020 National Basketball Association championship be a first-time champion?
column6: ['Sports']
Nuggets lost so the chance is now zero.
Can be resolved at 0, all franchises that have never won have been eliminated from the playoffs.

Only 1 option left with the nuggets having to win 3 straight games just to get to the NBA finals and then win the finals. There have been 257 3-1 series leads in NBA basketball history. only 12 times has a team come back to win after being down 3-1. This is only 4.6% of the time. However in the conference finals where teams are theoretically more evenly matched, this has happened 3/41 times or 7%.
Denver is the only one left in that category and they are down two games to none to LA Lakers. Last game was close but doubt that can pull off enough wins.
While I'd love to see Denver beat the Lakers, I don't think it will happen.
Chance of Denver winning the championship.
LeBron James is on a mission, as he was in Cleveland. He wants to win to honor Kobe, among other reasons.
Waiting to see how Nuggets do. Going to zero if they look incapable of beating the Lakers.

Nuggets is the only team remaining. They play the LAL in the WCF. The team showed mentality by coming back on two 1-3. However, with James and Davis in good form I predict this would not happen. They beat Clippers with Kawhi and especially PG underperforming.

Don't watch basketball or know a lot about it. Best guess right now, based on the lower player turnover when compared to other sports. So the teams that are good will stay good, low chance that less established teams will be able to compete with the more established ones.

Of the last four only the Nuggets franchise have not won a championship before, yet it also has the worst odds of winning. It will have to beat LAL (best team) and then whoever comes out the East (second best team). It beat the Clippers in large part because the Clippers massively under-performed, and has gone down 3-1 in both of its post-season series.
Nuggets still a longshot.
Just the nuggets remain.
Lakers beat Nuggets 3-1 in games this year. Odds makers have Lakers over all the teams left. Only Denver has never won a championship.
With Nuggets beating Clippers last night, FiveThirtyEight gives them a 12% chance of winning championship. [1]
3 out of 4 teams have at least 1 title. Denver will not beat LA, Bos, or Miami in back to back series.
Neither Denver nor the Clippers have ever eon a Championship. All Depends on if one of them can beat the Lakers. Doubt it after seeing how the Lakers took care of Houston.

It's either the Nuggets or the Clippers now. The Clippers we actually favored to take the title at one point, but they'v struggled in both series thus far. The Nuggets had to come back against the Jazz after falling to a 3-1 deficit in Series 1 and are attempting a similar comeback now after coming back from 3-1 to tie the Series 3-3 against Clippers. The Clippers have trouble sealing the deal and the Nuggets are flirting with fire going down so quickly. Unless this changes, neither team will have a chance against the Lakers, who are waiting patiently for the winner of Tuesday's game.
Not many first time teams left and they would have to get past the Lakers which will be hard.

2 of the teams still alive in the playoffs are part of the group of 11 NBA teams that have never won a championship. However, these 2 teams are currently playing each other in the Western Conference semi-finals so only one of them can advance. That means only 1 of the 4 representatives in the conference finals could be a first time champion. One of these potential first time winners, the Clippers, currently have the best odds to win the title.
Still don't think the Clippers can get past the Lakers.
I just have to align my forecasts...
The only team without a title is the LA Clippers. Nonetheless, it does not seem probable that they will be able to beat the LA Lakers in the conference finals.
continued track of 538
based on nba projection aggregate
While there are currently 2 teams in the conference semi-finals who are first-time winners, they are competing against each other and will be competing against better teams.
17% is a generous, crowd adjusted figure.
Crowd forecast is that Clippers will win the finals at 35% --> therefore, shouldnt this be near that same estimate???? I have my own doubts but these two predictions are a little contradictory.

With the elimination of the Pacers and the Magic, the only two first timers remaining are the Clippers and the Jazz are the only two remaining teams that fulfill the criteria. The Clippers and Jazz will potentially see each other in the second round. A sixth seed hasn't won since the 1995 rockets. Two seeds are extremely competitive each year. Since each team has to go through each other, downgrade to 28 on implied probability current odds.
Continuing to follow - https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/

Either the Jazz or the Nuggets will move onto the Quarter Finals, where they will most likely face the Clippers, meaning that by the Semi-finals there can be only 1 remaining first-time champion. The Clippers are the highest seeded team of the three, and historically speaking they have about an 11% chance of winning the title. However, their struggles against the Mavericks already and the complete dominance of Luka Doncic in the first series does not bode well for them against teams with the caliber and experience of the Lakers and Bucks. A weighted average of the three remaining teams gives a probability around 5%. Will update once Series 1 ends.
The Clippers might go all the way. I will keave for now but keep an eye on LAC.
I'm lowering my considerations slightly in the off chance that the clippers walk out of the bubble.

Currently, there are three teams remaining that can potentially be first time winners in the playoffs remaining: Clippers, Jazz/Nuggets. I'm counting the other 1-3 teams as losing the series overall. Only one of those teams in the west can make the finals, leaving the chances roughly at a 12.5% chance, if you consider it a 1/8 chance, regardless of skill of the teams. I personally believe that the Clippers increase their odds at beating any of Eastern conference teams, increasing the overall chance to 20%
Strange things happen, sometimes.

Only 4 teams remain that meet this criteria. The Nuggets and Magic are also only one game away from being eliminated, leaving only 2 that will likely make it to Round 2 of the playoffs. The Clippers have the best chance at success as a 2 seed, but they have struggled so far against the Mavericks, so their future prospects are not looking too good. Lowering my projection from 11 to 6 percent, will revisit at the end of round 1.
Big shift after Clippers performance
Clippers and Jazz are both leading in their respective series. Both are legit contenders.

Bumping down slightly - since I last updated before the playoffs started and several teams have been eliminated (Suns, Pelicans, Grizzlies) and others are on their way out (Net). While the Lakers had a shaky start they are looking better now, and PG is still playing below par for the Clippers.
Due to Doncic suffering ankle injury and Mavs dropping third game, balance shifts to Clippers having a better shot of making it through
Revised down in line with 538 numbers and Pat Beverly's injury

This is essentially a bet of whether the Jazz, Clippers, or Nuggets will win. With Jazz and Denver playing first round, this knocks down to either the Clippers winning vs. winner of Nuggets, Clippers. Recognize that the winner of this game will play each other, so once we reach the conference finals, we have at most 1 team to win it all. Naively assuming that each team has a 50% chance of winning, a first time champion would be .5*.5 = 25%, conditional on making to the conference finals. I would argue that Dallas has at least a 50% chance of taking the series against the clippers, which reduces the probability we would have a non-champion team in the western finals. Moreover, the individual strength of either the Nuggets or Jazz beating through the Western Finals and the NBA Finals against teams like the Clippers/Lakers/Bucks/Celtics is quite low, which also reduces my probability. Thus, my fair value is adjusted down to 10%, much of which is contingent on the Clippers. The clippers will most likely be facing either the Lakers or Rockets, both of which present mismatches to the playstyle. I favor the Lakers heavily over the Clippers, contingent on LBJ returning to playoff form and AD's health, and the Rockets v Clippers at least a coin flip since they split the regular season series. Bucks are also favored over Clippers, and thus halve my fair value to 5%.
Maintaining based on accuracy of earlier prediction on playoff-bound teams.
It all hinges on the Clippers. I don't see a scenario where they bypass the Lakers or Rockets... Let alone the Bucks or Raptors.
Lowest NBA finals seed winner in the last 10 years was a 3. Lowest to make a finals was a 4. Clippers and Denver come out of the west, and pacers have the best shot out of the east.
Took 538's odds for each team. They seemed pretty accurate. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/
Assuming Portland take the final remaining playoff spot, there will be 6 potential first-time winners out of 16 teams, giving a base rate of 37.5%. 3 of the last 10 winners have been first-time.

With Covid-19 sports are becoming much more unpredictable, thus having higher variance outcomes. This makes handicapping more difficult and likely favors outsiders (=first-time champions) relative to a regular season.

Of the teams that haven't won, only the clippers have anything greater than a 1% chance to win the title. While they are likely the 2nd or 3rd best team, their path to the finals will be difficult, and many of their stars are injury prone.

20 teams have split the 73 titles given thus far, meaning there have been 20 first-time champions, giving an anchor of 27%. It is easier for first-time champions in earlier years (i.e. the first team to win had a 100% chance), so we should lower this by a fair margin, say 14%. Of the 11 first-time teams, only 9 (the Nets, Nuggets, Pacers, Clippers, Grizzlies, Pelicans, Magic, Suns, and Jazz) were invited into the bubble. With 22 teams total in the bubble, if every game were a toss-up you would expect a 9/22 chance a new team would win (41%). Now, 5 new teams have qualified already for the playoffs, with the Nets right on the edge of qualification. Assuming they make it, that means 6/16 teams in the playoffs could meet this criteria (37.5%). However, only 2 teams (the Pacers and Nuggets) are ranked in the top 3 in their division, with the average playoff bound team ranked at 5. Given that a 7-game series tends are prone to less upsets than 1-game matchups, this does not bode well for this prediction, so I am knocking a few more points off the forecast to 11%.
https://www.theringer.com/nba/2020/7/28/21344494/the-ringers-nba-restart-odds-playoffs-lakers-clippers-bucks

Between the Clippers (35% odds making the finals and 60% odds of winning if they make the finals) and small but non zero probability of one of the other teams winning it for the first time, there is between 20 and 25% chance of a first time winner
Off to a weird start. Current picture: A combined 19.7% chance that we'll see a first-time champ. I'll update again as seeding is updated.

Until we see where the Clippers are at, I'm cautious vs the crowd. They have a shot, but everything working for and against them is working for and against the rest of the league. 10.6% of 2nd seed Western Conference teams have become champs as of 2017 (That number has shifted.) We'll have to see how the "regular" season record shakes out in the next few weeks: https://www.businessinsider.com/nba-playoffs-are-predictable-2017-5

To win a championship, if you are a team from the East, you need to beat the Celtics, the Raptors, or the Bucks, or two of them or all of them. Not going to happen. If you are a team from the West, you need to beat the Clippers, the Rockets or the Lakers, or two of them or all of them. Not going to happen. In the year that Kobe died, I would sell my house, car and gold tooth and bet it all on the Lakers. The most that can possibly even happen is an upset by the Bucks or the Clippers.

Of the 30 teams currently in the NBA, only 11 have never won a national title, putting the base rate around 37%. The average conference standing of these teams at the end of last season is around 7.6, and since you have to break the top 6 that means only 4-5 teams are likely to have a shot at the title of the 11, putting it closer to 20%. Since the teams are relatively evenly split between the two conferences, and 4 teams made the playoffs last season who haven't won a title, it's probably a little lower than 20%, so 18%.
Initial forecast. Of the eleven teams listed, only 2 are considered good. New bubble format might be easier for a team to sneak in, but doubtful. I liked @024_andrew analysis.
Of the 30 teams part in the NBA, 11 have never won the Championship before -> X = Likelihood of First Time Team Winning The 2020 NBA Championship X = 37% = 11/30

LA Clippers are the only viable candidate on the list. Although they are the frontrunners or at worst #2 most likely in the west, they could still lose prior to making the finals or in the finals to the Bucks. Also, any injury to Kawhi, PG, or Harrell drastically reduces odds of winning.

Of these teams, I think the Clippers are the only one with a meaningful chance of winning. 538's RAPTOR forecast pegs their chance at 23%, which seems about right to me. (Their Elo forecast puts it at 8%, but I think there's reason to believe their regular-season performance understates their postseason potential.) The Nuggets arguably have an outside chance, call it 1 or 2%. Maybe Indiana or Utah deserves a mention, but I'd put their chances at <1%.

I think only the Clippers have a legitimate chance of winning out of the teams that have never won a championship. I estimate their chances at about 25%. The Nuggets may have an outside shot (~1% ??).

The LA Clippers (25%) are the only team that I feel have a legitimate shot at winning the league from the above list. Denver Nuggets could be a fringe contender (1% chance). Apart from that, I think the Milwaukee Bucks (30%), the LA Lakers (20%), Boston Celtics (5%), Houston Rockets (5%) and the Toronto Raptors (5%) are the only actual contenders, while the Philadelphia Sixers could yet surprise (3%). Miami, OKC, Utah, Dallas are all fringe contenders otherwise.

Realistically, only the Clippers and Nuggets have a chance at being first-time champions. To get there they would have to get through each other, the Lakers, and probably the Bucks. It's possible, but I don't think it will happen this year.

Of the teams that have never won a title, only one team appears to have a legit shot. The Clippers may be the only team capable of winning but I would put their odds at 1 in 3, thus the 33 percent likelihood. The Jazz has an outside shot which pushes the likelihood to 34 percent, but it appears the Clippers are the only ones who can make it happen this year.

S Tier: Clippers - 18% American betting odds for the Clippers winning it all range from +280 to +340, which converts to implied odds of 22.7% - 26.3%. Sure these aren't true odds, but the crowd forecast of 8% already seems low. The Lakers are favorites to win, but the Clips have beaten them 2 out of 3 times this season and LA will be missing Rondo and Bradley. 2 seeds have a historical 14.7% chance of winning the title, but I give the Clippers an 18% chance of winning.

Of the 22 teams that remain, there are only 8 who have not won a championship. If they were to begin at this point with 0-0 records, this would still only allow for a 36% chance of one of them winning. According to betting odds, the Clippers are the primary team left with a shot. If the playoffs were to begin right away, the Clippers would be a second seed. As of 5 years ago, only 10 second seed teams had won a title. They would also have to defeated the favorited Lakers to get to the finals.

Of the 11 teams to have never won an NBA Championship, only 1 has a legitimate chance in my eyes to make a playoff run, and that's the Los Angeles Clippers. Brooklyn, Indiana, Memphis, Orlando, and Utah will all likely make the playoffs, but as bottom-half seeds. They will not have home-court advantage and will very likely not even make it past the first round. Before the season even started, I predicted a Milwaukee Bucks championship in 2020, and that seems to be solidifying, with the Los Angeles Lakers having a great season as well. The sort of "black sheep" of this list is the Denver Nuggets. They are an amazing team, 2nd in the Western Conference right now, but may not have the necessary playoff experience. Los Angeles Clippers 10% Denver Nuggets 3% Utah Jazz 1% Indiana Pacers 1% All Others 0%
Lakers will win.
2/12/2020 Standings vs probable outcomes:

Neither the Hornets, T-wolves, Pelicans, Magic or Suns are have winning records as of Feb 11th, 2020 (approx. half of the season). This leaves Grizzlies, Nets, Nuggets, Pacers, Clippers and Jazz as some kind of potential contenders. In my experience it is a better estimation to take the strongest contenders -by far- according to betting odds as of today, which are Bucks, Lakers and Clippers. Clippers are the only ones from the never-won list. Because of the series format in NBA playoffs (3 out of 5 or 4 out of 7), some level of randomness is taken away from the opportunity of a new team to win (unlike NFL or other direct-elimination sports). So I will take the 1 team that has more chance out of the 11 never-won list and then adjust a little lower since the Bucks are really the favorite team to win this year.

1. In 39 years, the team that won the NBA championship only once ranked outside the top 3 of the division --- 1994-95, so assuming the ranking remains unchanged, I have a high degree of certainty to exclude teams outside the top 3 of the division. . 2. It remains to be seen if the Jazz's deal works. The completion of the speedboat transaction is yet to be seen. Message 4 is my subjective probability reference.

Only the Clippers have a double-digit probability of winning the championship among those 11 teams. It currently sits at 19%, the Nuggets sit at 3%, the rest are under 1%. https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-nba-predictions/ Assuming that the Lebron is healthy in the postseason, I believe that he has the experience and push to move the needle beyond what the win-loss record provides.
Like NBa

7/16 teams currently in conference standing to be in playoffs have never won a championship. Only three of those are actually title contenders (Nuggets, Clippers, Jazz). NBA playoffs have minimal upsets. The current favorites are Bucks and Lakers. Lakers vs. these three teams are 3-3 thus far. Bucks vs. these three teams are 3-2 thus far. Still too early in season to predict playoff matchups and order. ~50% chance one of the three first-time teams will have the chance to play against Lakers. Give them 25% chance of upset. Give another 25% chance of upset against Bucks. 0.5 * 0.25 * 0.25 = ~0.03. Initial prediction, 3% chance the NBA champions will be a first-time champion.
11 of 30 teams sets base rate at 36.6%. The clippers (and maybe the jazz) are the only of those teams with a realistic shot at winning. So, dropping for initial forecast. .

The team representing the East will most likely be Milwaukee, barring serious injuries. The Bucks are currently a collective 6-2 against the top 7 teams in the West. Their two losses were against Utah and Dallas. Current Vegas odds list the Lakers tied with the Bucks at +275 to 300, followed closely by the Clippers (+300 to 333, or 23%). The Rockets are a distant fourth at +1000 to 1600 (5-10%). The rest of the teams have <5% chance.

Of the teams listed in the question, only the Nuggets, Pacers, Clippers, and Jazz have a chance of winning the NBA title. Per 538 [1], the Clippers have a 22% chance of winning it all, the Nuggets have a 2% chance, and the Pacers and Jazz have a 1% chance. This implies about a 25% chance of this question being answered with yes.
